Detailed Description

Raw Linux CANbus (SocketCAN) sockets.

Raw CAN sockets are comparable to using the old character drivers to send and receive individual CAN frames to one or more interfaces.

According to the SocketCAN notes: defaults are set at RAW socket binding time:

  • The filters are set to exactly one filter receiving everything
  • The socket only receives valid data frames (=> no error message frames)
  • The loopback of sent CAN frames is enabled (see Local Loopback of Sent Frames)
  • The socket does not receive its own sent frames (in loopback mode)

These can all be changed by setting options on the socket.

Gets the system time of the last frame read from the socket.

Returns
The system time of the last frame read from the socket with microsecond precision.

◆ last_frame_timestamp()

double sockpp::can_socket::last_frame_timestamp ( )

Gets a floating point timestamp of the last frame read from the socket.

This is the number of seconds since the Unix epoch (time_t), with floating-point, microsecond precision.

Returns
A floating-point timestamp with microsecond precision.

◆ set_filters() [1/2]

result sockpp::can_socket::set_filters ( const can_filter * filters,
size_t n )
inline

Sets the filters for receiving CAN frames on this socket.

A filter matches when: 

* <received_can_id> & mask == can_id & mask
*
Parameters
filtersThe CAN filters
nThe number of CAN filters.
Returns
true if the filters were set, false otherwise.

Member Data Documentation

◆ PROTOCOL_FAMILY

const int sockpp::can_socket::PROTOCOL_FAMILY = AF_CAN
static

The SocketCAN protocol family.

Note that AF_CAN == PF_CAN, which is used in many of the CAN examples.
